total_impedance_ori_txt: R1 and Rb0 connected in parallel so Ra0=R1*Rb0/(R1+Rb0)=500Ohm
total_impedance_txt: R1 and R2 connected in parallel so Ra0=R1*R2/(R1+R2)=500Ohm

total_impedance_ori_txt: R1 and R2 connected in series so Ra1=R1+R2=2kOhm
total_impedance_txt: R1 and R2 connected in series so Ra1=R1+R2=2kOhm

request.text: What is the voltage on R1?

solution: *** Solution by TINA assisted by AI ***
We have more than one generator so we are using superposition to calculate voltages/currents.
>> Pass1 started ...
>> Gen processing: IS1 ...
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (IS1)
R1 and R2 connected in parallel so Ra0=R1*R2/(R1+R2)=500Ohm
The total resistance is Ra0 = 500Ohm
Now we calculate the voltage on R1

We know that the voltage between IS1 nodes is 5.0V, because the generator current is Igen = 10mA and the resistance between the generator nodes is Rtot = 500Ohm so the voltage between the generator nodes is Igen*Rtot = 5.0V
All voltage generators have been replaced with a short circuit.
All current generators except for IS1 have been replaced with an open circuit.
(1) The components R1,R2 connected in parallel. The voltage on R1 is 5V because the voltage on Ra0 is 5V
>> Pass2 started ...
>> Gen processing: VS2 ...
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (VS2)
R1 and R2 connected in series so Ra1=R1+R2=2kOhm
The total resistance is Ra1 = 2kOhm
Now we calculate the voltage on R1
We know that the voltage between VS2 nodes is 0V.
All voltage generators except for VS2 have been replaced with a short circuit.
All current generators have been replaced with an open circuit.
(2) The components R1,R2 connected in series.
(2) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 0V.
(2) R1 is in the voltage divider so the voltage on R1 is R1/Ra1*0V = 0V.
Now we are using superposition to calculate the voltage on R1
Let's summarize the calculations from the previous section.
When you see subtraction here it means that the original direction reversed.
'voltage on R1' = 5V+0V = 5V
*** Passed ***: expected: 5, got: 5
